deliberation: Looked for metaphorical and idiomatic uses in the commissioning language. Considered ‘anointed’ as possibly literal (ritual) or metaphorical, and ‘captives’ as possibly spiritual, but those are not clearly figurative in this verse. Identified (1) the Spirit of the Lord being 'upon' the speaker as a spatial metaphor for empowerment, and (2) ‘binding up the broken-hearted’ as a medical/healing metaphor and conventional idiom for emotional healing.

instances.english_text: The spirit of my Sovereign GOD is upon me
vehicle: a tangible substance or presence resting upon someone
ground: being surrounded, controlled, and enabled by a powerful presence
effective empowerment and authorization
relation between divine presence and human agent
posture: confident acceptance of a bestowed role
instances.explanation: The Spirit of the Lord is pictured as something that can be ‘upon’ a person, using spatial language to metaphorically express divine empowerment and authorization.

instances.english_text: to bind up the wounded/broken of heart
target: those who are emotionally and spiritually devastated
inner emotional state of the afflicted
vehicle: a physically broken/wounded body part being bandaged
ground: damage needing careful treatment and gradual healing
restoration through attentive care
analogy between bodily and emotional healing
instances.explanation: The ‘heart’ is not literally broken, and ‘binding’ evokes medical bandaging. This is a conventional idiom and metaphor for healing deep emotional/spiritual wounds.

deliberation: Examined the temporal expressions and mourning language. ‘Comfort all who mourn’ can be literal consolation. The key figurative elements are ‘year of favor’ and ‘day of vengeance’, which depict divine action as if it were a calendrical period/event—blending metaphor and metonymy. I treat the ‘year’ phrase and the ‘day’ phrase as two parallel but distinct expressions.

instances.english_text: to proclaim a year of GOD’s favor
target: an extended period of divine goodwill and restoration
ground: a defined, official, and structured period marked by a particular character
a season set apart for a special purpose
analogy between festival/appointed years and eras of God’s action
posture: positive valuation of that appointed time
instances.explanation: The era of divine favor is spoken of as a ‘year’, using the concrete notion of a calendar year as a metaphor and metonymy for a distinct, divinely appointed season of grace.

instances.english_text: and a day of vindication/vengeance by our God
target: a decisive act or season of God’s judgment
vehicle: a short, specific point in time
ground: a sharply defined time characterized by a single dominant event
suddenness and definiteness
analogy between a calendar day and a climactic judgment-event
posture: sober but confident expectation of justice
assertion of God’s righting of wrongs
instances.explanation: God’s act of judgment is portrayed as a ‘day’ belonging to Him, using a literal day as a metaphor and metonymy for a focused, decisive intervention of divine justice.

deliberation: Reviewed the three ‘instead of’ phrases and the tree/planting imagery. The clothing/grooming terms contrast with ashes, mourning, and a faint spirit, expressing inner restoration with outer adornment imagery—three distinct but parallel metaphors. Then the people are titled ‘oaks of righteousness’ and ‘planting of YHWH’, extending an arboreal metaphor of stability and divine establishment.

instances.english_text: a turban/garland of beauty instead of ashes
target: the people’s restored honor and joy
vehicle: change in visible appearance from disfigurement to beauty
ground: transition from visible shame to visible honor
publicly recognizable change in status
analogy between outward adornment and inner condition
instances.explanation: While ashes were literally used in mourning, the exchange of ashes for a beautiful headdress functions as a metaphor for the move from humiliation and grief to public honor and joy.

instances.english_text: the oil of gladness instead of mourning
target: the experience of renewed joy granted by God
vehicle: anointing with fragrant oil at festal occasions
cosmetic/festive oil contrasting with disfiguring mourning practices
ground: joy that is both sensed and socially marked, like anointing oil
transition from sombre grief to festivity
analogy between pleasant fragrance and gladdened spirit
posture: hopeful promise of inner and communal celebration
positive valuation of God’s restorative action
instances.explanation: ‘Oil of gladness’ uses the cultural practice of anointing with oil at joyous occasions as a metaphor for a God-given state of rejoicing replacing mourning.

instances.english_text: a garment/mantle of praise instead of a drooping/faint spirit
target: the community’s renewed disposition of praise
vehicle: a cloak or mantle worn on the body
outer garment replacing a weak, languishing ‘spirit’
ground: praise becoming as visible and encompassing as a cloak
exchange of weakness for robust, outwardly evident worship
analogy between clothing and one’s enveloping inner state
posture: exultant anticipation of open, public praise
affirmation of God’s ability to transform inner dejection
instances.explanation: Inner dejection (‘faint spirit’) is contrasted with a ‘mantle of praise,’ using clothing imagery as a metaphor for a new, all-encompassing attitude of praise.

instances.english_text: they shall be called terebinths/oaks of righteousness
target: their character and standing as righteous
ground: stability, strength, and prominence associated with great trees
visibility and permanence of their righteousness
analogy between robust trees and an established righteous community
posture: celebration of their divinely given stability
instances.explanation: The community is metaphorically named ‘oaks of righteousness,’ likening their divinely restored righteousness to the strength and stability of great trees.

instances.english_text: the planting of GOD, for Him to be glorified
target: the same restored people as God’s handiwork
their divinely initiated and sustained existence
vehicle: a cultivated planting established by a gardener
ground: God’s deliberate establishment and care, like a gardener’s planting
their existence as a display of His skill and glory
analogy between a well-tended planting and a community shaped by God
posture: attribution of all credit to God
viewing the community as a showcase of divine glory
instances.explanation: Calling them ‘the planting of YHWH’ extends the arboreal imagery, presenting the people as a carefully established planting whose very existence displays God’s glory.

deliberation: The verse speaks of building ancient ruins, raising desolations, and renewing ruined cities. These terms can function symbolically for social and spiritual restoration, but the imagery is architectural and urban and can be taken quite straightforwardly as (promised) literal rebuilding after devastation. There is no clear, discrete metaphor or simile marked in the wording itself, so I do not isolate any necessary figurative expression here.

Considered whether ‘strangers pasturing your flocks’ and ‘aliens your plowmen and vinedressers’ might be primarily symbolic/metonymic for economic dominance. However, in context they plausibly describe literal service roles in an agrarian society, expressing reversal of status without requiring a distinct metaphor beyond that social picture. No explicit simile, metaphor, or personification is lexically flagged, so I treat the verse as primarily literal.

Examined titles (‘priests of YHWH’) and economic language. The priest/servant language may be literal or role-based rather than figurative. The phrase ‘you shall eat the wealth of nations’ clearly uses consumption imagery for enjoying foreign resources, a conventional metaphor/idiom that is distinct within the verse.

instances.english_text: You shall eat the wealth of nations
target: Israel’s enjoyment and use of other nations’ resources
vehicle: eating food for sustenance and satisfaction
ground: taking in and benefiting from something, as with food
complete appropriation and enjoyment of resources
analogy between consuming food and utilizing wealth
posture: celebratory assertion of reversal and abundance
instances.explanation: To ‘eat’ the nations’ wealth is an idiomatic metaphor: consumption of food stands for fully enjoying and appropriating the material resources of other peoples.

deliberation: Looked at the ‘double’ shame/portion language and ‘everlasting joy’. The ‘double’ language may echo inheritance practices and rhetorical contrast without clear figurative mapping in itself. ‘Joy everlasting’ overstates duration in human terms and functions as hyperbolic assurance of unending gladness in salvation-history perspective, which I treat as a distinct hyperbolic expression.

instances.english_text: Joy shall be theirs for all time / everlasting joy shall be theirs
target: the community’s future experience of gladness
stable, secure rejoicing in the restoration
vehicle: an unending, limitless stretch of time
ground: the idea that their joy will be so secure and lasting as to seem endless
emphasis on permanence and irreversibility
analogy between infinite duration and supreme security
posture: strong assurance intended to comfort and embolden
instances.explanation: Describing their joy as ‘everlasting’ functions hyperbolically (from a human temporal perspective) to stress the unshakable, enduring nature of the promised rejoicing.

deliberation: Considered ‘love justice’ and ‘hate robbery’ as possible anthropopathisms, but these are standard covenant-theological expressions. The key figurative element is ‘I will give them their work/wages in truth’, where divine recompense is framed in terms of an employer paying laborers—a metaphor/metonymy for God’s just reward.

instances.english_text: I will pay them their wages faithfully / in truth
target: God’s fair recompense for His people’s faithfulness
the outcomes and benefits granted by God
vehicle: an employer giving wages for completed work
ground: correspondence between labor and payment
certainty and fairness of receiving what is due
analogy between just employment practices and God’s justice
posture: assurance of God’s reliability and justice
positive evaluation of His covenant faithfulness
instances.explanation: God’s recompense is described with wage-paying language, an idiomatic metaphor/metonymy portraying His just rewards in terms of an employer paying workers what they have earned.

deliberation: The verse emphasizes recognition of descendants among the nations. ‘Seed’ (זֶרַע) is agriculturally derived but in Hebrew is a conventional term for offspring. This remains a figurative extension—metonymy/synecdoche from physical seed to a family line. I isolate that as the main figurative element.

instances.english_text: that they are a stock/seed that GOD has blessed
target: the descendants of God’s people as a recognizable lineage
ground: continuity, propagation, and origin associated with seed
growth from a source into a visible, fruitful outcome
analogy between agricultural seed and a family’s generational continuity
posture: honoring the lineage as God-originated and God-endorsed
instances.explanation: Using ‘seed/stock’ for descendants is a conventional metonymic and metaphorical extension from the agricultural domain, emphasizing their origin, continuity, and blessed fruitfulness as a family line.

deliberation: Identified two clothing metaphors (‘garments of salvation’, ‘robe of righteousness’) in parallel, where abstract benefits are treated as attire. Then noted two explicit similes: God’s adorning work is likened to a bridegroom and bride preparing themselves, grounding the earlier metaphors in familiar wedding imagery. These are four distinct but closely related figurative expressions.

instances.english_text: for He has clothed me with garments of salvation
target: the speaker’s experience of being saved and restored by God
vehicle: beautiful garments worn on the body
being dressed by another in special clothing
ground: protection, honor, and new status conferred by what one wears
visibility and completeness of the salvation experience
analogy between being clothed and being fully encompassed by salvation
posture: joyful gratitude for a bestowed status
public exultation in God’s saving act
instances.explanation: ‘Garments of salvation’ treats salvation as if it were clothing that God puts on the speaker, a metaphor expressing the completeness and public visibility of God’s saving work.

instances.english_text: He has wrapped me in a robe of righteousness
target: the speaker’s righteous standing or vindication before God
ethical and judicial rightness conferred by God
vehicle: a robe or mantle wrapped around a person
ground: being entirely covered and identified by what one wears
safeguard and honor surrounding a person like a robe
analogy between being robed and being fully enclosed in righteousness
instances.explanation: The ‘robe of righteousness’ continues the clothing metaphor, picturing righteousness as an enveloping garment that defines and protects the wearer.

instances.english_text: like a bridegroom adorned with a turban/garland
target: the speaker’s (or Zion’s) divinely given adornment and joy
the experience of being splendidly prepared by God
vehicle: a bridegroom putting on splendid headgear for his wedding
festal self-adornment on a wedding day
ground: festive beauty, honor, and joyful anticipation associated with a bridegroom’s attire
special, once-for-all celebratory preparation
analogy between bridal adornment and God’s lavish adornment of His people
posture: exultant comparison emphasizing dignity and joy
warm, affectionate valuation of God’s act
instances.explanation: The explicit ‘like’ (כ) introduces a simile: God’s adorning work is compared to a bridegroom splendidly dressing himself for his wedding.

instances.english_text: and like a bride bedecked/adorned with her finery
target: the speaker’s (or Zion’s) state of God-given beauty and joy
the fullness of adornment granted by God
vehicle: a bride adorning herself with her jewelry/finery
ground: maximum beautification, care, and joy at a wedding
being as adorned and prepared as possible
analogy between a bride’s jewelry and the honors God places on His people
posture: delighted, emphatic portrayal of honor and beauty
instances.explanation: Again with ‘like’ (כ), the text compares the speaker’s God-given adornment to a bride carefully ornamenting herself, intensifying the sense of beauty and joy.

deliberation: The verse is structured as an ‘as…so…’ comparison: earth/garden producing growth is paralleled with the Lord causing righteousness and praise to ‘sprout.’ The earth and garden are spoken of as active producers (mild personification), and righteousness/praise are treated as vegetation. Because these elements form one integrated agricultural image, I treat them together as a single extended instance that is both metaphorical and cast as a simile.

instances.hebrew_text: כִּ֤י כָאָ֙רֶץ֙ תּוֹצִ֣יא צִמְחָ֔הּ וּכְגַנָּ֖ה זֵרוּעֶ֣יהָ תַצְמִ֑יחַ כֵּ֣ן׀ אֲדֹנָ֣י יֱהֹוִ֗ה יַצְמִ֤יחַ צְדָקָה֙ וּתְהִלָּ֔ה
instances.english_text: For as the earth brings forth her growth and a garden makes the seed shoot up, so my Sovereign GOD will make righteousness and renown/praise shoot up
target: God’s bringing forth of righteousness and praise among the nations
the emergence and flourishing of just conduct and worship
vehicle: earth and garden causing plants and seed to sprout
natural process of vegetation growing from the soil
ground: gradual, organic, visible emergence and spread
fruitfulness and inevitability of growth given the right source
analogy between plant growth from soil and the arising of righteousness and praise from God’s action
posture: confident, hopeful assurance of fruitful divine work
positive evaluation of God’s life-giving power
instances.explanation: Using an explicit ‘as…so…’ structure, the verse compares God’s causing righteousness and praise to ‘sprout’ with the earth and a garden making plants grow, personifying the earth/garden and metaphorically treating righteousness and praise as vegetation.
